Battlefield has been a wonderful series, well at least the start and now the end. The explosiveness of the games has always attracted players and the sheer number of options to enter combat makes it all the sweeter. In short, Battlefield 6 feels like its return brought back what players expected, more of what they are familiar with but a little less of the new.¬†

Battlefield 6's (BF6) [b]gameplay[/b] is quite solid. All the [b]controls[/b] feel responsive and that the player has free ability to move and overcome obstacles. The choice of weapons and weapon attachments provides the players with a decent number of options to enter the battlefield (though the level up and unlock system may upset some Gamers who want to use a specific loadout - I think it's fine but the new update with the battle pass sort of seemed to skew the exp gained a little). Players are equipped with a primary weapon, secondary, throwable, and a few deployable options as well (which includes launchers and other potential special abilities that come with the class). As usual there are four different classes: assault, engineer, recon, and support. Vehicle [b]controls[/b] can range from simple to difficult depending on what you're driving. The helicopters and airplanes will take some practice if left on their standard [b]controls[/b], but their controls can be switched to a more friendlier piloting systems for those that just want to fly in the sky. The amount of modifications for the vehicle load out was also another solid feature to the game, even though it may not be completely new. Firing a gun feels impactful and the player can certainly feel it with well-timed rumbles to the controller.¬†

The [b]graphics and visuals[/b] are quite stunning, and amazingly unlike Call of Duty, the shaders don't take 300 minutes to load up. There is a lot of chaos, a lot moving elements in the environment to symbol that chaos, and the fact the player can change the visuals by interacting with them (or more like, crashing or blowing up through them) is quite amazing. This has been one of the biggest differences between the Battlefield series and other games where everything remains static. The map doesn't change its layout (unfortunately like the BF4 map with the high rise), but cover and buildings get blown which causes players to reflect on their approach. The [b]sounds and music[/b] were absolutely well done as well. Playing off of speakers still let's the player hear quite a bit (running / footsteps, fly over of a jet, rumbling of a tank near a building), but playing with headphones let's the player hear a heck of a lot more with solid stereo effects. Both parts of these domains were done well and truly feels like a solid effort was put forth to immerse the player further into the game.

Overall, would highly recommend. The price is quite steep from what I'm used to, so waiting for a sale is of course recommended, but if this is your cup of tea and you love sinking hours into a war game - certainly go for it. Adding a [b]campaign[/b] and lots of multiplayer type games will certainly keep players busy in what they want to play. I do miss the small changes some maps had like Battlefield 4 (high rise map where the high rise could be brought down) as I found that quite innovative, but BF6 does have a decent and some solid set of maps. There is a lot can be broken, but I feel more could've been destroyed in BF4.¬†

Another issue is the fact you can't customize the gunner seat to your needs, since who ever gets in the vehicle first dictates what the gunner gets to use in their preset. Next we have weapon attachment issues. There's a lot of attachments that take time to unlock and you would think they would make your gun better, but in reality they make them worse. If, like me, you were looking forward to playing this game because of the whole "It's like classic battlefield" marketing. I would say hold off. It is [i]so very close[/i] to that. There are just a few issues in the current state of the game that, for me personally, hinder the experience.

First off, the complete lack of an official server browser (yes I know the server browser exists for community made portal content) makes playing, at the best of times, simple. You only need to press two buttons and you queue for a match. However, at the worst of times, you can be sat at the start of the match for sometimes upwards of five minutes waiting for people to join, only for the lobby to be flooded by bots and making the first five to ten minutes of a match extremely boring. I have no idea why they removed this, as in previous games (most of my playtime being in BF4/1) you could choose the mode you wanted to play and it would find a lobby for you, but you could also go through the (much better) server browser. This led to matches being full from the start and being able to play multiple matches with the same teammates, which for a team based multiplayer shooter was much better as an experience.

My second issue is the class system. I like that they have made an attempt to fix some of the issues that were there in the beta, for example giving the assault class a more defined role than just run around and shoot people. My main issue with the classes is the "consolidation" of the medic/support role, which on paper is great but leads to both of the roles feeling worse to play overall. I think the idea of making the same bag both heal/resupply teammates is cool, but as someone who primarily plays the "medic" role in team based games I feel like the healing system is just subpar when compared to games like BF4/1. For one the medic pouch from previous games is now locked behind 4 assignment steps rather than class levels (which from what I can gather don't exist anymore?) or even just account levels. I will say that the other classes seem okay, though I have only played a little bit of engineer and recon (not assault). Though there is the downside of respawn beacons being removed from recon and moved to assault.

My final main issue is the weapon level system. There are 50 levels per gun. I understand that compared to something like Battlefield 4 there are many more attachments per weapon (especially considering most attachments in that game were locked behind battlepacks) and I also understand this isn't a yearly COD game where, from what I can remember (haven't got recent experience), you can level up guns in a matter of a few matches. I find that most of the attachments don't make a big enough difference to merit multiple tiers, though I haven't done extensive testing. For example 3 different tiers of vertical foregrip that as far as I can tell from the modding screen don't change the stats of the weapon depending on which you have equipped. The whole needing to get through 50 levels to get the ability to mess around with attachments is extremely slow and boring, I think the highest gun I have managed to get in my ~12h of multiplayer is 31 or 32, mostly because I want to try a different gun (which you then have to spend hours grinding) before I can finish levelling.

All of this being said I don't think this game is bad, far from it. It is MILES better than 2042, though I'm not sure that is saying much. I just feel like we shouldn't settle for better than the worst game of the franchise, when IMO it doesn't outdo previous instalments that came out 10+ years ago. That being said, this game feels great to play, the gunplay is great, like your character is holding an actual rifle rather than the admittedly airsoft-y feel that battlefield 3/4 had with a lot of guns. It sounds amazing too, the audio is extremely immersive and I really appreciate the tinnitus settings as someone who can struggle with that in some games. Obviously this is the best looking battlefield game, but that isn't just in terms of fidelity, I don't like using the word "vibe" when trying to describe something but I hope you will understand what I mean when I say each map has the vibe of an actual battle.

But hey! Maybe I'm just being picky and I should just be happy that we have a better battlefield game again. I just feel like this game is like 75% of the way to being perfect and I can't help but want the extra 25%. You might disagree with me and you would be right if you do. Anyone's opinion is correct for them but I just wanted to write my feelings on this game for anyone who might be in a similar situation to me. Also I will continue to play this game, I'm not using this review to say it's awful or unplayable, but to be a small voice hoping to push the game the final stretch to being amazing. I love the battlefield franchise, it holds a special place for me in gaming, which probably leads me to be more critical than I otherwise would be, so also keep that in mind.

[b][h1]REDSEC (BATTLE ROYALE) MODE REVIEW BATTLEFIELD 6[/h1][/b]
So, where to start? I guess I'll start with why the review is negative and whether there are ways to turn the many negative reviews into positive ones. Let's begin:

[h3]SHOOTING[/h3]

The game has a terrible shooting system, and it's full of bugs! ADS Bloom is an outdated mechanic that no longer applies and does not level the playing field between PC and console players. It's incredibly frustrating when you take aim and start shooting at an enemy standing 50 meters away, and only 2-3 bullets out of your entire magazine hit their target. The same situation occurs at a distance of 5-10 meters. The entire magazine of a PW7 or any other SMG is used to inflict 160 damage on the enemy, and if they have a machine gun, they will outgun you, even if they are standing still. NONSENSE!!! Why not resort to adding a stronger visual recoil and making it a hit scan (removing the spread and making the weapon 100% accurate). That's the skill-dependent basis of shooting. With over 15k hours in online shooters, when you enter Battlefield 6, you don't control your shooting with your skill... Sorry, but this seems like a complete failure and incompetence on the part of the developers responsible for balance! The developer promised to fix this in the October 28 patch, but alas, the lines are in the patch notes, but there are no changes in the game!

[h3]BALANCE[/h3]

Also, regarding balance, I can say that Battle Royale mode has the same flaws. Why the hell are there tanks in the game? It's too much! They literally destroy everything in their path. Okay, let's imagine that tanks are a distinctive feature of Battle Royale from Battlefield and they are not going to remove them. In that case, I suggest balancing their use. Since in 8 out of 10 games in the endgame there is at least one tank on the map, let's go the following way - all tanks start to detonate, similar to the existing sabotage mechanic, as soon as there are 10 squads left on the map! Voila! ‚Äî the presence of tanks in the game is balanced! 
Next, we have a second chance system, and it's like a stopgap in this game, since nothing better has been come up with yet. Even if you play like a complete idiot, you have a 100% guarantee that you can return to the game. Why??? There is no risk and no tactics involved! The game is already very similar to [spoiler]CoD's WZ[/spoiler], and besides, there is an excellent second chance mechanic there, namely ‚ÄúGulag.‚Äù Make something similar, for example, one of the Gauntlet round modes, only 1 vs. 1 and with shorter mission conditions. In any case, it's better than a free return to the battlefield!

[h3]SOUNDS[/h3]

Sounds... Very strange sound behavior, at least in Battle Royale mode. In the main game client, I like the sounds, especially in Night Mode. I can hear literally every step and distinguish its direction. But in Battle Royale mode, I may not hear a tank 10 meters away from me. The ambient noise is too loud, and the sound reflection is very poor. I can hear the enemy about 2 out of 5 times. Also, I often hear only one enemy running behind a wall. I come out to face them, and there's a whole squad there, which guarantees my death. Terrible, absolutely terrible. The developer who worked on the sound map definitely didn't work on it in this mode; everything was done automatically with AI, at least that's how it looks.

[h3]VISIBILITY[/h3]

This is both a good and bad feature of the game. The game looks gorgeous. Every time I am surprised that an online game with 100 players playing simultaneously can look so good and optimized. But, sometimes I just can't see my opponents. Yes, an identifier in the form of a red square often appears above them, but if the enemy is more than 50 meters away, they are not always marked even on the map, or they blend in very strongly with the background of rocks, sand, and other debris. I can offer my own solution. I really like the setting from [spoiler]CS2[/spoiler] - ‚ÄúHigh contrast enemies‚Äù. When enabled, enemies appear with a barely noticeable halo, which makes it easy to spot enemies that blend in too much with their surroundings. It doesn't make them stand out too much in the overall picture, but against the backdrop of such a busy image as in Battlefield 6, it will allow attentive people to really see the enemy.

[h3]BUGS[/h3]

As for bugs, I often see enemy recons units hitting their drones to fly into the sky. Or how fast people fly off the ladders of assault, pushing off from them. Oh, and how annoying is the bug where, when shooting after strafe or jump (with sufficient delay), I don't hit the target, but it's as if I'm shooting from the hip. Why are there no hotfixes? We have to wait for a major patch to fix these annoying bugs (P.S. in the October 28 patch, there are only changes in the patch notes, but in the game itself, the bugs are still present and working).

[h3]ARE THERE ANY WAYS TO FIX IT?[/h3]

Yes, there are, and plenty of them! 
The game is very good, but only in its main mode so far. The RedSec mode was rushed out to drown out the hype of competitors, which seems obvious. I believe in Battlefield, that they will be able to retain their audience and gain many new ones, but there is a lot of work to be done! First, fix all the critical bugs and errors, namely ADS Bloom, various exploits, and the most nasty visual bugs, such as self-destructing houses. Next, you need to work on the sound, overall visibility, and balance. THAT'S IT! The game will be as comfortable to play as possible for 90% of players! 
Otherwise, the game is extremely good! The optimization is excellent, the response is very fast, even with frame generation I don't feel any input lag. The animations deserve special applause. The movement is also well done. Not as fast as in [spoiler]CoD[/spoiler] and not too slow. In general, it's perfect!
